descriptionSet.description: The image shows a woman sitting crosslegged on a carpet and reading the holy Koran which rests on a carved book holder. In the background we can see several religious articles like a lamp and incense.

inscription.text: Impregnated Safety Matches C. A. Mohammad. The Esavi India Match Fct. Made in Calcutta

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: Impregnated Safety Matches C. A. Mohammad. The Esavi India Match Fct. Made in Calcutta

description-en: The image shows a woman sitting crosslegged on a carpet and reading the holy Koran which rests on a carved book holder. In the background we can see several religious articles like a lamp and incense. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The figure of a reformist, literate Muslim woman shown on a matchbox becomes a trope heavily used in the Nehruvian period, and most often pictured with a background of scenes from the Middle East to suggest the “two worlds” inhabited by Indian Muslims (that of the fore-grounded India and the Islamicate world in the background). (Sandria B. Freitag)(gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The woman's literacy and demeanor suggest a reformist tradition. (Sandria B. Freitag)(gs)
related literature: Braudel, Fernand 1981. "The Structures of Everyday Life". London: Collins. (gs)
related literature: de Certeau, Michel 1984. "The Practices of Everyday Life" . Berkeley: University of California Press. (gs)

related literature: Freitag, Sandria 2007. "South Asian Ways of Seeing; Muslim Ways of Knowing: The Indian Muslim Niche Market in Posters" in Indian Economic and Social History Review, 44:3 (2007):297-331 (gs).
related literature: Freitag, Sandria B. 2010. "Consumption and identity: Imagining ‘Everyday Life’ Through Popular Visual Culture" (gs)
related literature: Storey, John 1999. "Cultural Consumption and Everyday Life". New York: Oxford University Press. (gs)
